titleproper.value:
Guide to the John Kissam papers
                    <num>1974.133</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Larry Weimer

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-02-08T15:12-0500</date>

extent.value: in 16 folders in one manuscript box

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The John Kissam papers (1778-1823; 1864-1868) principally include correspondence and orders to Major Kissam, a Loyalist, concerning the Queens County Militia during the British occupation of New York and Long Island during the American Revolution. The subjects relate mostly to the taking of property, especially wood-cutting; authorization for movements about Long Island and to New York; and meeting troop musters. There are a small number of post-war items concerning Kissam. The collection also includes election (1865) and discharge (1868) certificates for Corporal Platt Wiggins from the New York State National Guard and the August 1864 muster roll of Company K of the 12th Georgia Infantry Regiment, Confederate States of America.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); John Kissam papers, 1974.133, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Sources: Henry Onderdonk Jr.'s 
                <emph render="italic">Documents and letters intended to illustrate the revolutionary incidents of Queens County, N.Y.</emph> (on the Brooklyn Historical Society library shelves at call number F127.Q3.Q4 v.4), especially pages 31-59; Edward Kissam's 
                <emph render="italic">The Kissam family in America from 1644 to 1826</emph> (call number CS71.C3883), page 25.

The collection also includes election (1865) and discharge (1868) certificates for Corporal Platt Wiggins from the New York State National Guard. The collection includes the August 1864 muster roll of Company K of the 12th Georgia Infantry Regiment, Confederate States of America.
